title: 5 ultra-cheap e-paper projects anyone can set up
description: ePaper is fantastic for adding context displays around your home
author: Joe Rice-Jones
excerpt: ePaper is fantastic for adding context displays around your home
text: I love ePaper and E-Ink in all its forms, whether I'm reading eBooks, taking notes, or browsing the Internet for sparks of inspiration. I love seeing all the projects that people have used ePaper displays on, adding dashboards of various sizes that don't drain your electricity bill. I wish more options to use it for computing use existed, but that would require larger display sizes which get spendy really quickly. But for small projects, ePaper is one of the most economical ways to put a device with a screen together. While the panels can be more expensive than LCD models of similar size, they're easier to power, so you can save on battery size or power supplies, enabling tiny projects that really stand out. And once you're finished, you can use that display and SBC to make another project, and another, making the overall cost low. Related There's more than one ESP32, and here are the differences between all of them If you're looking to take the plunge into the world of ESP32 devices, then here's a basic overview of what you need to know. 5 A smart home monitor with ESPHome Give your desk a gorgeous display for the things that matter most Smart home monitoring via Home Assistant and ESPHome is a natural place to use ePaper, as the reflective panels' fade-into-the-background nature makes for perfect ambient computing. Once you've got ESPHome on something like the Seeed Studio ePaper Panel, and Puppet running in Home Assistant to send dashboard views over to the display, the only question is which parts of your smart home are necessary as always-available metrics. This could be the weather, the temperature on the thermostat, a calendar, and your daily tasks, or it could include anything you want, like a floor plan of your home and icons to indicate if windows or doors are closed or open, or anything else you can connect to Home Assistant. As it turns out, it is pretty much anything you can think of, between official integrations and the ability to bring API calls from other devices into the fold. Related 4 A screen to tell you the weather It's far more elegant than looking out the window The weather might be constantly changing, but not fast enough to need anything faster than ePaper's refresh rate. Building a weather forecaster can be done in various ways with an ePaper display and low-powered maker boards pairing together to show the current weather conditions. Using an ESP32 instead of a Raspberry Pi is probably cheaper, but then it might be harder to build, so the decision is yours. Either way, you get an unobtrusive weather monitor that can sit on your shelf and tell you if you need an umbrella if you're going out, or if you want to leave the house at all. Related Build your own elegant e-paper weather display powered by an ESP32 microcontroller If you want a gorgeous e-paper weather display, the design work has already been done for you with this ESP32 project. 3 A tiny ESP32-powered smart display I love the idea of choosing only the information you care about Microcontrollers and SBCs like the ESP32 and Raspberry Pi are perfect for powering low-cost display projects, and this tiny ePaper display cuts down on costs and the amount of data you can display. Honestly, I don't like too much data on my dashboards as it gets me all confused, and this teeny-tiny dashboard is just about big enough to show the contents of a tweet, or whatever they're called these days. The project is set up to show the time, weather, Pi-hole statistics, and the current view count of the author's personal website. I can only imagine the site views counter is going wild with how much attention this awesome project is getting, and I kinda want one to put on my desk to track my weekly metrics. Related 2 A stylish clock Who wouldn't want to tell the time with this minimalist display Source: YouTube Many maker projects start with a Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W, and for good reason. These tiny, low-power SBCs are perfect for putting into smart displays, lightweight print servers, and keeping smart homes ticking over. This inexpensive project turns an ePaper screen and picture frame into a gorgeous clock, with a few added extras if you want to use them. While the clock face is undoubtedly the star of the show, the InkyPi also has plugins for image upload, showing newspaper front pages from around the world, the weather, your calendar, and a few generative AI tools for new images and random text. To get started, you'll need a Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W, 3, or 4 and one of the ePaper displays mentioned on the project's GitHub page. You don't have to splurge for the color options, but they do make the clock faces stand out even more. Related 1 Make a versatile calendar Inkycal is your Raspberry Pi Zero W's new best friend Source: Inkycal Inkycal is now in its third iteration, and the Python-based dashboard is a fantastic use of ePaper displays. It's built on Debian Bookworm, but be warned that the installation process can be lengthy. In the worst case scenario, one of the packages, numpty, could take several hours to install. Inkycal has pre-installed ready-to-flash versions if you become a GitHub Sponsor, which helps with maintenance costs (and your sanity). Inkycal does the things you'd expect from the name, including a monthly calendar, daily agenda, and image slideshows, but it does a few things that I've not noticed on any other smart display project: Todoist synchronization Stock tickers iCanHazDad jokes XKCD comics RSS/ATOM feeds You'll also need a Raspberry Pi, a universal ePaper driver board for 24-pin SPI, and an 8GB MicroSD card. Some configuration via SSH will be required to get the SPI driver board for the display working before you can install Inkycal. You can even run the whole thing via battery with a PiSugar battery pack, and there are full instructions for how to do that on GitHub. Inkycal ePaper is fantastic for personal projects The awesome thing about all of these projects is that the hardware can be reused for other projects, so you're not stuck with one end result. One day, your ePaper could be a handy calendar, keeping the family organized. The next, it could be an open-source eReader to catch up on your backlog of eBooks. There is almost no end to projects you could build, and once you learn enough, you can have a go at creating something from scratch, including all the code to get it working. Related 5 Raspberry Pi projects you can complete in a weekend If you've got a free weekend, why not use it to complete one of these useful Raspberry Pi projects?
